content:
⚠️ Modified the contribution.
Comment: 
Changed constraints from 1≤[[n]]≤10**6 to 1<[[n]]≤10**6
n = 1 would be a tricky edge case, and since it's not actually included in your tests or validators, I think it's best to make it clear to clashers that they don't need to worry about n = 1.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution beacuse it's clear and simple

It wouldn't hurt to include a little more explanation in the problem statement:

"For example, [[n]]={{20}} has two prime divisors, 2 and 5. The smallest integer with two prime divisors is {{6}}, with divisors of 2 and 3."

Even being an obvious statement, it might have helped me solve it in less time to be illustrated so clearly. My solution was correct, but more involved than it needed to be. And as a result, it took me longer than 5 minutes.

But I say this primarily for those who are staring at the puzzle with their head spinning. The problem is so concise that the meaning is going to be lost on some people. If they downvote, it will get yanked. Trust me, I've been there!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: very fun to try and golf it. here is my first solution that i came up with to golf in ruby:
require'prime'
p Prime.each.lazy.take((2..n=gets.to_i).count{n%_1<1&&Prime.prime?(_1)}).reduce :*

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one :)

Yeah, I didn't come out with a golf solution ^^"
I believe other people would be way better than me to it, so the golf mode is for them ^^'
